hotspots.hotspot:
Demand-pull inflation

Demand-pull inflation results when all sectors in the economy try to buy more goods than the economy can produce. Prices are "pulled up" by excessive demand.

Example of demand-pull effect

When corn was demanded for ethanol fuel, there was a shortage of corn for animal feed. The shortage resulted in higher prices for corn, which resulted in higher prices for animal feed, which resulted in higher prices for steak.

Cost-push inflation

Cost-push inflation results from rising input costs, especially energy costs. More expensive inputs "push up" the cost of products for manufacturers, and thus cause inflation.

Example of cost-push effect

Rising oil prices raise the prices of everything from plastics and gasoline to shipping costs, airline fares, and cosmetics.

Wage-price spiral

According to the wage-price spiral, inflation occurs because higher prices force workers to ask for higher wages. If workers get the higher wages, producers try to recover that cost with higher prices. As each side tries to improve its position, the rate of inflation keeps rising.
